children.subject: You cannot use 47D to fulfill the L&S CS requirement - this is just to help you get ready for 16B (should you feel the need for the structure of a class - you’re always free to just self study if you have enough self discipline and would prefer that approach).

Out of curiosity, why is this the case that we can not use 47D to fulfill the graduation requirement, especially if we have taken Math 54 (and maybe other linear algebra classes) before? Seems like it would develop the full skill set for EE16A, or maybe I don't know enough . about the course yet :)

This is a perfectly reasonable question, and I’m happy to answer.  The reason is that we believe the real requirement should be EE16A (or Math 54) + EE16B, and for students admitted Fall 2017 and later, that is indeed what is required.  Since it obviously wouldn’t be fair for us to retroactively change the requirements for students who were already here, we do still allow Math 54 + 16A, but that “legacy”/fairness consideration is the only reason we still allow this.  47D didn’t exist until Fall 2017 (i.e., it has no legacy considerations associated with it) and 54 + 47D definitely doesn’t cover the material from 16B, so that’s why that doesn’t fulfill the graduation requirement.
That makes complete sense, thank you so much!
So will 47D + 16B fulfill the L&S CS requirement?

Math 54 + 16B fulfills the requirement - whether you also took 47D or not doesn’t really matter from that standpoint.  (I assume that you weren’t asking about taking just 47D without having taken Math 54, but that assumption was incorrect please do let me know.)

Thank you for replying! 

I'm taking placement test for Math 54, which fulfills the requirement of Math Department, but I'm not sure if it is acceptable for CS Department.
Does EE47D plus Math 54 fulfill the EE16A requirement for the EECS major?
Would this course fulfil the L&S Computer Science requirement or was it just to progress to 16B?
I don't know if it will be offered, but if it is, it will be the same session as 16A
It seems unlikely that 47D will be available over the summer, however we'll follow up with Professor Alon and check
I would like to follow up if this class would be offer this Summer 2018. Thank you.
We are not currently planning on offering 47D this summer.  Feel free to reach out to me directly about the specifics of your situation and I can try to advise you as to the best path forward.
Will this class be available during the summer? If so, which summer session?

I'd imagine it would be of similar difficulty (maybe a little easier) since you're effectively just taking the last two-thirds or so of 16A without the requirement of doing the labs (which are roughly 1.5-3 hours a week depending on how time-intensive a given lab is). If you have a solid linear algebra background you should be fine since the first several (5 or so) weeks of the course (module 1) cover introductory linear algebra material.

If you want to check out what the course covers in general, the course website for this semester is here.
In honest opinions (from anyone), How difficult would this class be compared to 16A? Especially if I'm taking it with 61B? I have a strong linear algebra background.
I don't believe so, but you're welcome to contact Professor Alon
Is this course offer in the summer?
Yes.
Do we have to do the homework for Module 3?
Yes.
Will this class (with math 54) fullfill the EECS minor requirement for 16A?
Yes and Yes!
Can EECS 47D students attend EE16A discussion sections? Also, can EECS 47D be taken as P/NP?
Hi! I updated the original post.
Who do we email for the Fall 2018 offering of EECS 47D?
Definitely by the add deadline at the latest. However, I would reach out to the faculty to see when they plan to stop doing the administrative processes to enroll/onboard new students.
Is there a deadline to enroll in 47D? I still want to be enrolled in 16A, but am not sure now with the current position I am in (I am 135 in the waitlist).

history.content:
In an attempt to answer questions that many of you have been asking about in one place, I would like to provide some information about EECS 47D (the EE16A bridge course that for most students who sign up for it, serves as a way of preparing for the circuits content in EE16B after having taken Math 54 and understood that material well).

 

* 47D is not in practice an independent class - it is a simply a mechanism by which you can receive credit (and a grade) for completing portions (but not all) of 16A.  

 

* To "make-up" the circuits material from 16A, one would enroll in 47D for 2 units.  In terms of requirements, this would mean that starting from module 2 (~6 weeks in to the semester), at the same times/pace as the 16A students, a 47D student would submit all of the homeworks (and the self-grades), take midterm 2, and take the final exam.  The grade for 47D would be based only on these components (using the same weights as used for 16A, just re-scaled to make the total weight add up to 100%).  47D students are encouraged but not required to complete the labs (and discussions); if at any point the labs/discussions become physically full (as defined by the fire marshall), the 16A students would get priority.

 

* 47D students can go to any lab section they would like, as long as they email the Head TA with the lab TA of that section CC'ed for prior approval. Again, the Head TA or lab TA have the right to say no to 47D students attending their section if the labs become physically full.

 

* 47D students have equal access to all of the course's staff/resources (office hours, homework party, etc.) as 16A students.  

 

* In order to enroll in 47D, you will need a code for the course. So, if you are interested in potentially enrolling in 47D, please send the EE 16A instructors an email describing your background (specifically, that you took math 54 and have checked your understanding of those concepts by e.g. looking at previous 16A offerings' homeworks and successfully solving them) and certifying that you have read and understand this post.
history.subject: Information about EECS47D (EE16A bridge)

history.content:
In an attempt to answer questions that many of you have been asking about in one place, I would like to provide some information about EECS 47D (the EE16A bridge course that for most students who sign up for it, serves as a way of preparing for the circuits content in EE16B after having taken Math 54 and understood that material well).

 

* 47D is not in practice an independent class - it is a simply a mechanism by which you can receive credit (and a grade) for completing portions (but not all) of 16A.  

 

* To "make-up" the circuits material from 16A, one would enroll in 47D for 2 units.  In terms of requirements, this would mean that starting from module 2 (~6 weeks in to the semester), at the same times/pace as the 16A students, a 47D student would submit all of the homeworks (and the self-grades), take midterm 2, and take the final exam.  The grade for 47D would be based only on these components (using the same weights as used for 16A, just re-scaled to make the total weight add up to 100%).  47D students are encouraged but not required to complete the labs (and discussions); if at any point the labs/discussions become physically full (as defined by the fire marshall), the 16A students would get priority.

 

* 47D students can go to any lab section they would like, as long as they email the Head TA with the lab TA of that section CC'ed for prior approval. Again, the Head TA or lab TA have the right to say no to 47D students attending their section if the labs become physically full.

 

* 47D students have equal access to all of the course's staff/resources (office hours, homework party, etc.) as 16A students.  

 

* In order to enroll in 47D, you will need a code for the course. So, if you are interested in potentially enrolling in 47D, please send the EE 16A instructors an email describing your background (specifically, that you took math 54 and have checked your understanding of those concepts by e.g. looking at previous 16A offerings' homeworks and successfully solving them) and certifying that you have read and understand this post.

history.subject: Information about EECS47D (EE16A bridge)

history.content:
In an attempt to answer questions that many of you have been asking about in one place, I would like to provide some information about EECS 47D (the EE16A bridge course that for most students who sign up for it, serves as a way of preparing for the circuits content in EE16B after having taken Math 54 and understood that material well).

 

* 47D is not in practice an independent class - it is a simply a mechanism by which you can receive credit (and a grade) for completing portions (but not all) of 16A.  

 

* To "make-up" the circuits material from 16A, one would enroll in 47D for 2 units.  In terms of requirements, this would mean that starting from module 2 (~6 weeks in to the semester), at the same times/pace as the 16A students, a 47D student would submit all of the homeworks (and the self-grades), take midterm 2, and take the final exam.  The grade for 47D would be based only on these components (using the same weights as used for 16A, just re-scaled to make the total weight add up to 100%).  47D students are encouraged but not required to complete the labs (and discussions); if at any point the labs/discussions become physically full (as defined by the fire marshall), the 16A students would get priority.

 

* 47D students can go to any lab section they would like, as long as they email the Head TA with the lab TA of that section CC'ed for prior approval. Again, the Head TA or lab TA have the right to say no to 47D students attending their section if the labs become physically full.

 

* 47D students have equal access to all of the course's staff/resources (office hours, homework party, etc.) as 16A students.  

 

* In order to enroll in 47D, at least for Fall 2017 and Spring 2018 (and most likely moving forward as well), you will need a code for the course.  So, if you are interested in potentially enrolling in 47D, please the instructors an email describing your background (specifically, that you took math 54 and have checked your understanding of those concepts by e.g. looking at previous 16A offerings' homeworks and successfully solving them) and certifying that you have read and understand this post.  

#pin
